results.title: L'apprenti Salaud = the Apprentice Heel
results.brief_description:
Antoine was a pleasant and agreeable man for years, until a small inheritance begins to give him some dangerous ideas about gaining wealth and women. Partly in order to win the affections of a young woman, he becomes a small-time con man on the basis of some ideas his accountant has planted in his mind.

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Michel Deville ; writer, Michel Deville ; photography, Claude Lecomte ; music, Georges Bizet.
Cast: Robert Lamoureux, Christine Dejoux, Claude Pieplu, Georges Wilson, Jean-Pierre Kalfon, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze, Jean-Francois Derec, Bernard Lavalette, Annick Blancheteau.

results.title: Le Rat D'amerique = the Rat Trap
results.brief_description:
Charles migrates to Paraguay. He meets Maria, a young cashier in money changing outlet and falls in love with her. Short of money and short on prospects, Charles becomes involved in a gun smuggling

Credits: Director, Jean-Gabriel Albicocco ; writers, Jacques Lanzmann, Jean-Gabriel Albicocco ; photography, Quinto Albicocco ; music, Georges Garvarentz.
Cast: Charles Aznavour, Marie Laforet, Franco Fabrizzi.

results.title: Jeannot L'intrepide = Fearless Johnny
results.brief_description:
During a walk, Jeannot and his brothers become lost in the forest. While trying to find their way back, they enter the house of the ogre.

Credits: Director, Jean Image ; writers, Jean Image, Eraine, Paul Colline ; photography, Kostia Tchikine ; music, Rene Cloerec ; animation, Andre Champeaux.

results.title: L'intrepide = the Intrepid
results.brief_description:
Didier, a surgeon in a Paris hospital, saves the life of Canello, a famous gangster. In order to show Didier how grateful he really is, Canello offers to eliminate Lydie, Didier’s overbearing fiancee. The contract on Lydie must be executed during an overnight train trip. But at the last minute, Lydie gives her seat to an other woman. Didier must now save the woman from becoming a victim of Canello.

Credits: Producer, Alain Darbon ; director, Jean Girault ; writer, Jacques Wilfried, Andre Versini, Rene Versini ; photography, Guy Suzuki ; music, Raymond Lefevre.
Cast: Louis Velle, Claudine Auger, Juliette Mills, Roger Hanin, Michel Galabru.

results.title: L'heritier = the Heir
results.brief_description:
Bart Cordell inherits his father’s business following his father’s accidental death. Bart is convinced the circumstances of this death were dubious and may be part of a ploy to destabilise his financial empire. He hires a private detective and finds that a reporter working for his father’s magazine (one of the many companies he owned) was looking into plans by another multinational to take over the company. Cordell also discovers that his father-in-law, a former Italian fascist, may not have given up his old loyalties.

Credits: Producer, Jacques-Eric Strauss ; director, Philippe Labro ; writers, Jacques Lanzmann, Philippe Labro ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Michel Colombier ; art direction, Theobald Meurisse.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Carla Gravina, Jean Rochefort, Charles Denner, Maureen Kerwin.

results.title: La Traversee de Paris = Four Bags Full
results.brief_description:
A wealthy artist and a simple cab driver join up to transport four suitcases of blackmarket pork across Paris during the Occupation, dodging German roadblocks, hungry dogs and collaborators. Awards: Venice Film Festival 1956: Best Actor for Bourvil.

Credits: Producer, Yves Laplanche ; director, Claude Autant-Lara ; writers, Jean Aurenche, Pierre Bost ; photography, Jacques Natteau ; music, Rene Cloerec ; art direction, Max Douy.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Bourvil, Louis de Funes, Janette Batti, Robert Arnoux, Georgette Anys, Anouk Ferjac, Bernard Lajarrigue.

results.title: La Fete Sauvage = the Wilderness Party
results.brief_description:
Animals around the world are shown, primarily in the wild. The movie indicates a strong preference to leave animals in their habitat rather than put them in zoos.

Credits: Director, Frederic Rossif ; writer, Madeleine Chapsal ; photography, Bernard Zitzerman ; music, Vangelis Papathanassiou.
Cast: [Original French narration] Evelyne Dress, Gerard Falconetti, Myriam Mezieres.

results.title: Le Journal D'un Fou = Diary of a Madman
results.brief_description:
This adaptation of the Russian classic is set in Paris in 1963. Pascal is slowly losing grip on reality. Living in a state of permanent exaltation, he confides all his dreams to his diary, in particular, his ambition to become Ferdinand VIII, King of Spain.

Credits: Producer, Paul Joly ; director, Roger Coggio ; writers, Marcel Moussy, Sylvie Luneau, Roger Coggio ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, George Delerue.

results.title: Les Deux Anglaises et le Continent = Anne and Muriel
results.brief_description:
Based on Roche’s autobiographical second novel, ‘Two English Girls’ is an inverted version of Jules and Jim set in the Belle Epoque with two English girls, sisters of very different temperament, throughout their lives loving the same man - a Frenchman. Truffaut’s alter ego, Leaud, brings his persona of solitariness and passivity to the character of Claude at the apex of the triangle. Although both films are about wasted lives, ‘Two English Girls’ is sadder and more complex than Jules and Jim which is dominated by “Moreau’s charismatic capriciousness which spills all over the movie”, to quote Pauline Kael, giving it more vitality. ‘Two English Girls’, with its detached narration, is more introspective, dealing with emotions at one remove - ‘feelings about feelings’.

Credits: Director, Francois Truffaut ; writers, Francois Truffaut, Jean Gruault ; photography, Nestor Almendros ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Leaud, Kika Markham, Stacey Tendeter.

results.title: La Baie des Anges = Bay of Angels
results.brief_description:
An ordinary bank clerk who has had a streak of good luck at the Nice casino, falls in love with a compulsive gambler, who has left a husband and child to satisfy her craving. Shot very quickly on the French Riviera, this love story with a roulette wheel as the motif and the motive, is one of the most vivid evocations of gambling fever on film. The luminous photography and the hypnotic music add to the film’s attraction. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producer, Paul-Edmond Decharme ; director, Jacques Demy ; writer, Jacques Demy ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Michel Legrand, art direction, Bernard Evein.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Claude Mann, Paul Guers.
